story:
Short Summary

As a nurse and a healer I have had the amazing opportunity to touch many lives, and be touched in return. How Shall I Heal is based upon my years of traditional nursing, the stories are real, the emotions raw. It is the ultimate " Everyone has a story" as I have woven the fabric with the richness of tradition, emotions, heart wrenching transparency and the love that I have been witness to. This book has been in the concept stage for the past 10 years, in the written stage for a year. It was inspired by a conversation with a man who knew the value of life much more intimately than many. Below is a tiny segment of the story. 

          " It was about this time that I realized how intertwined our lives as nurses became with how we identified ourselves. I was no longer Jill, I was a nurse, mother, wife, advocate, friend and it would be years before I could untangle myself to realize I was Jill, a creature of the Universe. We lose our identity in what we do, forgetting who we really are. I’m not saying that is altogether a bad thing, but when we do this we lose our essence. Most people live their entire lives this way, and become so caught up in their identity, their egos and reputation that they fail to grow beyond those things, and in doing so do not necessarily become the true blessing they could be. Here in this hospital filled with sickness, pain, hopefulness and hopelessness, I began to realize that when the spirit shows through, we can grow and nurture not only others but ourselves. Here I learned the value of living a meaningful life.  The difficulty I'd experienced with others who were not touched in this manner, including some of my own family, is that they simply didn't get it and couldn't understand that life is to be lived, love shared and relationships cherished. While I knew it in my heart, living this way was not easy, established relationships tend to stagnate, unless both parties desire to move forward, learning stops, and seams tear. "

Your contributions in whatever form they come can bring to life a story that has been waiting to be told and the time is now. So many people are searching for healing and it does not always come in the way we think. Be open, believe and be willing to accept the possibility that there is another way. Namaste' ( I bow to the divine in you !)

What We Need & What You Get

I am seeking $18,000 to fund my mission of getting this book published and in the hands of as many people as I can. As a holistic health care consultant I see , feel and experience the need of so many who are struggling with illnesses of all forms. My greatest desire is to see this book go viral! 

Working as a consultant allows me the freedom to choose my schedule and follow my heart and for that I am grateful. In order to market this book what I need most is time and a cash flow to allow me to focus on making this  happen. 

Please check out the perks of funding this project and give as your heart dictates. I am so willing to share my story, knowledge and gifts that I have offered some perks that can change, and enhance your life. If you do not have the financial resources to contribute I ask that you do so by sharing this message with as many people as you know. I believe with all of my heart and soul that there is a way to reach my goal and I will be forever grateful for any assistance you can lend. 

If I do not reach my campaign goal you can be sure that I will find a way to make it happen. I have been nicknamed " The junkyard dog" for a reason. When I believe in something I will not let it go until I find a way. 

The Impact

I believe with every fiber of my soul that this book has the potential to change many lives. I went from being a traditional nurse working challenging jobs in ER, ICU, Oncology and more to living a life of a holistic practitioner because I saw that we need more than traditional medicine to heal. We need to get real, and understand that there is a way to heal that is yours to discover. 


Risks & Challenges

I worked and lived " traditional" medicine until 2001 when I was diagnosed with a disease that disrupted my life, left me in pain so severe for weeks at a time that I lost portions of my life. I discovered after a two year battle that the illness had an emotional connection, and once I understood , accepted and then healed that I began to live my life in a whole new way. This story is the beginning of the journey, and touches on the beginning of the healing. Book two " Now That I Have Healed" is in the works! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Your contribution in whatever form it comes will be greatly appreciated! If you find you cannot contribute financially I ask you to consider spreading the word via email, word of mouth, social media or anywhere you feel relevant. Much love and blessings in abundance to all! 
If you have any questions or comments please contact me via email. Check out my website for a peak at the work I do now. 
Email : nursemomjmm@yahoo.com
http://roadstowellness.biz/

story:
MY PASSION

Hi! I'm Jill Davis and I LOVE The Beatles!

And...I want to share that love of The Beatles, their music and their impact on the world of music with my grandchildren and the children of the world. YOU can help me achieve this goal through contributions aimed at completing the illustrations and publishing process for my book B Is For Beatles.

MY BACKGROUND

I was an elementary school teacher for 33 years.


I know children's literature and I know how much children love rhyming and the order of the alphabet. So it made perfect sense to me that writing a child's rhyming ABC book would be a beautiful way to share The Beatles with kids.
MY DREAM

My best friend Sue and I had our dream come true when we went on a Magical History Tour for 11 days to London, Liverpool and Hamburg. We were able to see, touch and hear the real places and events that shaped The Beatles and their music. So much Beatle history... enough for every letter of the alphabet!


MY COSTS

I didn't know it would be so expensive! Here are my costs to finish the illustrations, publishing and printing of my book.

And even if I don't reach my goal, (which I will, of course!) the funds I receive will still go toward the publishing of the book. Any and all funds will help me tremendously!

MY PERKS

I have some awesome perks for your generous contributions to this project. You can view them in more detail to the right. Everything from a signed first edition of the book, a signed watercolor print of one of the fabulous illustrations, a T-shirt of  B is for Beatles....

And even the opportunity to have your picture incorporated into one of the illustrations Sgt. Pepper-style!

Wouldn't it be cool to have your portrait or your child's or grandchild's portrait done in the style of the book by the illustrator, Jeanne Conway? That's another perk!

MY ILLUSTRATOR

Jeannie McGauley Conway is an artist and also an illustrator, working mostly in watercolors.  She is a member of the Society of Children’s Book Writers and Illustrators (SCBWI) and most recently illustrated Dina Anastasio’s children’s book entitled “The Storm” published by Pearson Digital Library.

In addition to her own art, she has been an art teacher for 27 years.  She has taught ages 5 to 18 in St. Louis (her home town) and in London, England.  She is currently teaching art at an elementary school in south St. Louis county.

YOUR CONTRIBUTION

If you feel like I do, that The Beatles' impact on the world is timeless and historic, then please join me as I work to complete the illustrating and publishing of this book that I hope will serve as a link to future generations. 

Also, please spread the word about B Is For Beatles by sharing the link on your social media sites and by telling your friends, neighbors and co-workers about it.

Thank you so much!

WE CAN WORK IT OUT..... TOGETHER

Here are two more illustrated pages from the book. It is so exciting to see my words come to life through the art!

Any and all funds will help me tremendously!MY PERKSI have some awesome perks for your generous contributions to this project. You can view them in more detail to the right. Everything from a signed first edition of the book, a signed watercolor print of one of the fabulous illustrations, a T-shirt of  B is for Beatles....And even the opportunity to have your picture incorporated into one of the illustrations Sgt. Pepper-style! Wouldn't it be cool to have your portrait or your child's or grandchild's portrait done in the style of the book by the illustrator, Jeanne Conway? That's another perk! MY ILLUSTRATOR

Jeannie McGauley Conway is an artist and also an illustrator, working mostly in watercolors.  She is
a member of the Society of Children’s
Book Writers and Illustrators (SCBWI) and most recently illustrated Dina
Anastasio’s children’s book entitled “The Storm” published by Pearson Digital
Library.
In addition to her own art,
she has been an art teacher
for 27 years.  She has taught ages 5 to 18 in St. Louis (her home town) and
in London, England.  She is currently teaching art at an
elementary school in south St. Louis county. YOUR CONTRIBUTIONIf you feel like I do, that The Beatles' impact on the world is timeless and historic, then please join me as I work to complete the illustrating and publishing of this book that I hope will serve as a link to future generations. Also, please spread the word about B Is For Beatles by sharing the link on your social media sites and by telling your friends, neighbors and co-workers about it.Thank you so much!WE CAN WORK IT OUT..... TOGETHER
Here are two
more illustrated pages from the book. It is so exciting to see my words come to
life through the art!

Enter the MADHOUSE: Illustrated Shared World Horror Anthology Published by Dark Regions Press - Dark Regions Horror #1

In the middle ages, it was thought that insanity was contagious. Centuries on, we label such ideas as superstitious ignorance. But when John Doe begins to speak after decades of silence, the staff and patients at the Golden Canyon Behavioral Health center begin to realize that behind every superstition lies a horrid truth.

On the night that a vicious sandstorm closes the roads and seals the doors, a plague of madness spreads through the hospital. Two staff members try desperately to hold onto their sanity while searching for the cause - and, hopefully, the cure - of the outbreak.

But they're not alone. In this shared world anthology edited by Brad C. Hodson and Bram Stoker Award® winner Benjamin Kane Ethridge, some of the genre's most talented authors present their own sanity shattering tales. With fiction by John Skipp, Jeff Strand, Scott Nicholson, Lisa Morton, John Palisano, and many others, the horrible truth is revealed bit by awful bit. Step inside and find out what it's truly like in the MADHOUSE.

Megan Hart writes books. Some of them use bad words, but most of the other words are all right. She can't live without the ocean, can't write without music, and she can't stand the way corduroy feels. Find her at www.meganhart.com

Artist Aeron Alfrey has worked on many projects, most notably Thomas Ligotti titles such as Noctuary, Songs of a Dead Dreamer and Grimscribe: His Lives and Works. We are honored to have him as the sole artist on MADHOUSE, and included in our campaign goal are 10 interior illustrations by Aeron based on the stories within. Depending on the success of the campaign, as many as 30 additional interior illustrations could be added.

Featuring Stories from Award-Winning and Renowned Authors like John Skipp, Scott Nicholson, Lisa Morton, Mercedes M. Yardley and Many More

MADHOUSE contains 18 stories of psychological horror from many renowned authors of horror and dark fiction as well as 20 chapters and an epilogue of a meta plot following the nightmarish happenings at the Golden Canyon Behavioral Health Center. It is the first title in the new Dark Regions Horror line designed with collectors in mind.

Inside Golden Canyon Behavioral Health Center, a mysterious visitor wakes a patient from a decades long catatonic state. The events that follow plunge the hospital deep into a fever nightmare as two employees struggle to keep their sanity long enough to puzzle out the truth behind the infectious madness sweeping through Golden Canyon. 

- Chapter 1, Chapter 2, Chapter 3 -

Sean has always been able to hear the thoughts of those around him. For someone with Sean’s “gift,” Golden Canyon quickly reveals itself to be an unpleasant place.

- Chapter 4 -

When Tim comes to visit his aging sister Lily at the hospital, he finds that she has developed a wondrous and hellish gift.

- Chapter 5, Chapter 6 -

Dr. Edlehart’s controversial treatments are used in an attempt to heal Jeffrey Jackson, but the repercussions of such therapy reverberate throughout Golden Canyon.

- Chapter 7, Chapter 8 -

James Klein has been having problems since his return from Iraq, but Dr. Ruiz didn’t realize the extent of them. God is a bug and the sands blow in thick and hot.

When the water goes down the basin, it sounds like the pathway to hell . . . 
For Golden Canyon patient Claire Stallings, the nightmare is about to begin.  

- Chapter 9, Chapter 10 -

Kelsey’s best friend inside Golden Canyon is her nurse Jen-Jen. But not even Jen-Jen can silence the voice of the devil-doll.

- Chapter 11 -

The Sandman is coming. William knows that. John Doe told him. And soon everyone at Golden Canyon will know.


Ewan and Miranda deal with the horror of the Sandman unleashed as the hospital goes mad around them.


The story of the Sandman comes to an eerie close.

- Chapter 12 -

Birdman struggles against the staff of Golden Canyon as he rushes toward a meeting with an angel. 

- Chapter 13, Chapter 14 -

Franklin and Sugar are playing a dangerous and violent game. The prize for winning? Freedom. The penalty for losing? Their lives.

Golden Canyon’s abusive orderly gets his just desserts.

- Chapter 15 -

Dr. Sarah McManus discovers firsthand just how depraved the infectious madness at Golden Canyon can get. But unlike the others suffering from whatever virulent madness sweeping through the hospital, she’ll put her new-found depravity to good use.

Sennel and Gwen find themselves in a battle with demons both real and imagined and, worse still, each other.

Tilly comes to Golden Canyon to meet the man who molested her as a child. Her therapy won’t be complete, she knows, until she writes one final letter from this place to Dollie.

- Chapter 16 -

A maddening secret behind Golden Canyon is revealed.

- Chapter 17 -

As the plague takes over the hospital, Skylar deals firsthand with the pandemonium now surrounding her.

No one has ever believed Trisha. Why should going mad change anything?

- Chapter 18, Chapter 19 -

Several of Golden Canyon’s women – Doctors and inmates and others – find their stories converging in the most epic and insane foodfight ever written.

- Chapter 20, Epilogue -

The Editors

Brad C. Hodson does uncredited rewrites for movies you will never see. His short fiction can be seen all over the place and his first novel, DARLING, is available through Bad Moon Books. When not writing, Hodson is the Administrator for the Horror Writers Association. He enjoys travelling, lifting heavy things made of iron, and writing about himself in third person. For more information on where to find his material, please check out www.brad-hodson.com.

Benjamin Kane Ethridge is the Bram Stoker Award winning author of the novel BLACK & ORANGE (Bad Moon Books 2010). For his master's thesis he wrote, "CAUSES OF UNEASE: The Rhetoric of Horror Fiction and Film." Available in an ivory tower near you. Benjamin lives in Southern California. When he isn't writing, reading, videogaming, Benjamin's defending California's rivers and streams from pollution.

Say hi and drop a line at ben@bkethridge.com


Associate Editor

R.J. Cavender is an Associate Member of the Horror Writers Association and the thrice Bram Stoker Award® nominated editor of the +HORROR LIBRARY+ anthology series and co-editor of HORROR FOR GOOD: A CHARITABLE ANTHOLOGY, both from Cutting Block Press.

He is the managing editor of horror at Dark Regions Press, editor-in-chief at the new Cutting Block Books, acquisitions editor at Blood Bound Books, and pitch session coordinator for World Horror Convention. He is also the founder of The Stanley Hotel Writers Retreat.

R.J. lives in Tucson, Arizona. His favorite book is THE SHINING. 

He can be contacted at: horrorlibrary@hotmail.com


The Artist

Aeron Alfrey creates unique imagery inspired by the macabre, grotesque and monstrous. His art has been published in numerous books and shown in galleries around the world.


The Authors

John Palisano's short fiction has appeared in many places. Check out: Horror Library, Darkness On The Edge, Lovecraft eZine, Phobophobia, Lovecraft eZine, Harvest Hill, Halloween Spirits, the Bram Stoker nominated Midnight Walk, and many other publications. NERVES is his latest novel. He is working hard on its sequel, as well as many other upcoming works.

"Available Light" was nominated for the Bram Stoker Award® in 2013. "The Geminis" was nominated for the Bram Stoker Award® in 2014.

John's had a colorful history. He began writing at an early age, with his first publications in college fanzines and newspapers at Emerson in Boston. He's worked for over a decade in Hollywood for people like Ridley Scott and Marcus Nispel. He's recently been working as a ghost-screenwriter and has seen much success with over a dozen short story sales and his novel NERVES gaining critical and reader acclaim. There's more where that all came from. Lots more. His novel DUST OF THE DEAD will be released by Samhain in June.

You can visit him at

www.johnpalisano.wordpress.com

Christopher Conlon is a writer, poet, and editor whose best-known book is his Richard Matheson tribute anthology He Is Legend, a Bram Stoker Award-winning compilation of original stories from Stephen King, Joe Hill, Whitley Strieber, and many others. He has written novels, including the Stoker Award finalists A Matrix of Angels and Midnight on Mourn Street, along with volumes of poems, collections of short stories, and a stage play. He lives in Silver Spring, Maryland.

Scott Nicholson’s first novel "The Red Church," inspired by an actual haunted church near his home, was released as a mass market paperback in 2002. It was selected for three book-of-the-month clubs and was a Bram Stoker Award finalist. His other novels are "The Harvest" and "The Manor."

Nicholson won the grand prize in the international Writers of the Future contest in 1999. That same year, he was first runner-up for the Darrell Award and his work was recommended for both the Stoker and Nebula Awards. He studied Creative Writing at Appalachian State University and UNC-Chapel Hill and served as secretary for the southeastern chapter of the Mystery Writers of America. He’s published over 40 stories in six different countries, some of which appear in his collection "Thank You For The Flowers."

Nicholson was born in Mooresville, NC, and has lived in many NC towns, including Goldsboro, Asheboro, Sylva, Taylorsville, Forest City, Gastonia, and Tryon. He works as a journalist in the Blue Ridge mountains near Boone, NC. His former jobs include carpenter, dishwasher, musician, house painter, radio announcer, and baseball card shop owner.

Nicholson has also published many writing articles, and his website www.hauntedcomputer.com features a number of author interviews, articles, and fiction.

Erik Williams is a Defense Contractor, former Naval Officer, Iraq War Veteran, and former Kenpo Karate instructor. He is the author of DEMON, WALKING SHADOWS, BLOOD SPRING, and numerous short stories. He has three daughters and is undergoing testosterone treatments to continue to feel like a man. Erik Williams is the Demon Squid.

Sara Brooke is an international Amazon bestselling author who writes horror and suspense novels.

A lifelong avid reader of all things scary, Sara's childhood dream was to write books that force readers to sleep with their lights on.

Her first novel, Still Lake, was released Spring 2012.

Sara's influences and favorite authors include Bentley Little and John Saul.

She is presently working on her next novel.

Born in Laredo, Texas, Thersa Matsuura grew up in Alaska, Florida, South Carolina and Nebraska before settling down in Japan. A resident of Japan for over twenty-three years, she now lives with her Japanese husband and their seventeen-year-old son in Yaizu, a small fishing town near Shizuoka.

Thersa Matsuura started writing short stories in the late 1990s. Her debut collection of short stories, A Robe of Feathers, was published by Counterpoint in 2009. Currently, she is working on her first novel.

Sheldon Higdon is an author with numerous publications in various magazines and books. Everything from short stories to non-fiction articles to poetry. He is also an award-winning screenwriter.

www.sheldonhigdon.com.

Anthony J. Rapino resides in Northeastern Pennsylvania, somewhere between the concrete of the city and the trees of the forest. On occasion, you'll find him moderating the feverish battles between the creatures of these two arenas. Whose side he's on is anyone's guess.

His debut novel, SOUNDTRACK TO THE END OF THE WORLD, is now available in limited signed hardcover and trade paperback editions from Bad Moon Books: http://www.anthonyjrapino.com/fiction-in-print/soundtrack-to-the-end-of-the-world/

Most recently, he has published two audio books, available exclusively through In Ear Entertainment: https://www.inearentertainment.com/usd/product-category/audiobooks-us

Other fiction can be found in issues of Black Ink Horror, On Spec, Arcane, Electric Spec, A Capella Zoo, Space Squid, TQR Stories, and carved inside a variety of autumn gourds.

Proof of his psychosis can be found on his website: http://www.anthonyjrapino.com

Mercedes M. Yardley is a dark fantasist who wears stilettos and poisonous flowers in her hair. Her short story collection, Beautiful Sorrows, came out in the fall of 2012, and her novella Apocalyptic Montessa and Nuclear Lulu: A Tale of Atomic Love came out in September of 2013. Her debut novel, Nameless: The Darkness Comes, released in January 2014. It is the first book in The Bone Angel Trilogy.


Max Xavier has been writing since the moment she could hold a pen.Her short stories, poetry, and essays have been read around the world,to audiences of every age. A canvas and clay artist and photographer, as well as an accomplished poet, her work can be found in museums and in private collections across the United States. 

Sam W. Anderson lives in Denver, Colorado with a lovely family that disavows any knowledge of his existence.  It’s best for their reputation.  He’s the author of POSTCARDS FROM PURGATORY and THE UNUSUAL EVENTS OF A SATURDAY AFTERNOON AT BIG K’S TRUCK STOP AND FINE DINING EMPORIUM – A MONEY RUN TALE.  His Money Run stories have drawn a cult following, and Horror-Web described the fictional world as: “becoming something more than just a series of stories but a whole new world, J.R.R. Tolkien created Middle Earth and Sam W. Anderson created The Money Run … and to be honest, The Money Run is much more my kind of place than Middle Earth ever was.”  Also, he likes pie.

Meghan Arcuri writes fiction and poetry.  She lives with her family in New York’s Hudson Valley.

Please visit her website at http://meghanarcuri.com

Lisa Morton is a screenwriter, author of non-fiction books, award-winning prose writer, and Halloween expert whose work was described by the American Library Association's READERS' ADVISORY GUIDE TO HORROR as "consistently dark, unsettling, and frightening". She began her career in Hollywood, co-writing the cult favorite MEET THE HOLLOWHEADS (on which she also served as Associate Producer), but soon made a successful transition into writing short works of horror. After appearing in dozens of anthologies and magazines, including THE MAMMOTH BOOK OF DRACULA, DARK DELICACIES, THE MUSEUM OF HORRORS, and CEMETERY DANCE Magazine, in 2010 her first novel, THE CASTLE OF LOS ANGELES, was published to critical acclaim, appearing on numerous "Best of the Year" lists. Her book THE HALLOWEEN ENCYCLOPEDIA (now in an expanded second edition) was described by REFERENCE & RESEARCH BOOK NEWS as "the most complete reference to the holiday available," and Lisa has been interviewed on The History Channel and in THE WALL STREET JOURNAL as a Halloween authority. She is a six-time winner of the Bram Stoker Award®, a recipient of the Black Quill Award, and winner of the 2012 Grand Prize from the Halloween Book Festival. A lifelong Californian, she lives in North Hollywood, and can be found online at www.lisamorton.com.

G. Daniel Gunn is the pseudonym of Bram Stoker Award horror author Daniel G. Keohane, author of MARGARET'S ARK and SOLOMON'S GRAVE. His short stories have been published in a number of major horror magazines and anthologies over the years, including Cemetery Dance, Apex Digest, Shroud Magazine, Fantastic Stories and many others. He's received multiple Honorable Mentions in the annual Year's Best Fantasy and Horror / Best Horror of the Year.

Kim Despins lives and plays in Colorado. Her work has appeared in a number of anthologies and magazines including Shocklines: Fresh Voices in Terror (forthcoming from Cemetery Dance) and On Spec magazine.

She collaborated with her writing group Snutch to create Tales from the Yellow Rose Diner and Fill Station, a well-received and unique collection of stories that explore some of the ugliest moments in the lives of the diner's patrons.

Kim's greatest desire is to spend a single night with S. Clayton Yurpecs, drinking decent wine and painting each other's toenails.

The Keeper is her first novel.

Robin Spriggs is the author of Diary of a Gentleman Diabolist, Wondrous Strange: Tales of the Uncanny, The Dracula Poems, Capes & Cowls: Adventures in Wyrd City, and nearly 200 short stories and poems that have appeared in a wide variety of publications. His work has been nominated for a Bram Stoker Award, Pushcart Prize, and multiple Rhysling Awards. His next book, The Untold Tales of Ozman Droom, is slated for release in 2014.

As an actor, Spriggs has appeared as Captain Franco in NBC's Revolution, Chris Amante in USA Network's Necessary Roughness, and as affable sociopath Alfonse Duncan in the rural noir Sinkhole. He is currently attached to the romantic comedy The Genesis of Lincoln and the horror film The Ballad of Jimmy Hallows.

Rena Mason is the Bram Stoker Award® winning author of The Evolutionist and East End Girls. A longtime fan of murder mysteries, horror, sci-fi, and history, she began writing stories to incorporate her favorite genres along with career and life experiences into suburbia.

Currently, she is a resident of Las Vegas, Nevada with her family but she grew up as a military brat and has lived in eight states ranging from Hawai'i to the Florida Keys. An avid SCUBA diver for over twenty years, she has done some wreck diving, ice diving, and just about everything in between. Travel has always been a big part of her life, and her favorite place to vacation is The South Pacific. To learn more about this author visit her website at: www.renamasonwrites.com

“Jeff Strand is a funny, deeply disturbed individual.” —Jack Ketchum, author of Off Season and The Girl Next Door

Jeff Strand is the three-time Bram Stoker Award nominated (and three-time Bram Stoker Award non-winning) author of such novels as Pressure, Dweller, Wolf Hunt, A Bad Day For Voodoo, Graverobbers Wanted (No Experience Necessary), Benjamin’s Parasite, The Sinister Mr. Corpse, Fangboy, and a bunch of others. He lives in Florida, where all of the whackos reside, although he was insane before he moved there. He will give you a great big hug if you visit his Gleefully Macabre website at http://www.jeffstrand.com

John Skipp is a New York Times bestselling author, editor, zombie godfather, compulsive collaborator, musical pornographer, black-humored optimist and all-around Renaissance mutant. His early novels from the 1980s and 90s pioneered the graphic, subversive, high-energy form known as splatterpunk. His anthology Book of the Dead was the beginning of modern post-Romero zombie literature. His work ranges from hardcore horror to whacked-out Bizarro to scathing social satire, all brought together with his trademark cinematic pace and intimate, unflinching, unmistakable voice. From young agitator to hilarious elder statesman, Skipp remains one of genre fiction's most colorful characters.

The Publisher

Dark Regions Press is an independent specialty publisher of horror, dark fiction, fantasy and science fiction, specializing in horror and dark fiction in business since 1985. We have gained recognition around the world for our creative works in genre fiction and poetry.  We were awarded the Horror Writers Association 2010 Specialty Press Award and the Italian 2012 Black Spot award for Excellence in a Foreign Publisher. We produce premium signed hardcover editions for collectors as well as quality trade paperbacks and ebook editions.  Our books have received seven Bram Stoker Awards from the Horror Writers Association.

We have published hundreds of authors, artists and poets such as Clive Barker, Joe R. Lansdale, Ramsey Campbell, Kevin J. Anderson, Bentley Little, Michael D. Resnick, Rick Hautala, Bruce Boston, Robert Frazier, W.H. Pugmire, Simon Strantzas, Jeffrey Thomas, Charlee Jacob, Richard Gavin, Tim Waggoner and hundreds more.  Dark Regions Press has been creating specialty books and creative projects for over twenty-nine years.

The press has staff throughout the United States working virtually but also has a localized office in Portland, Oregon from where we ship our orders and maintain the primary components of the business.

Dark Regions Press staff, authors, artists and products have appeared in FANGORIA Magazine, Rue Morgue Magazine, Cemetery Dance Magazine, Dark Discoveries Magazine, Publishers Weekly, Kirkus Reviews, Booklist Online, LA Times, The Sunday Chicago Tribune, The Examiner, Playboy, Comic-Con, Wired, The Huffington Post, Horror World, Barnes & Noble, Amazon, iBooks, Sony Reader store and many other publications and vendors.

Dr. Edlehart’s controversial treatments are used in an attempt to heal Jeffrey Jackson, but the repercussions of such therapy reverberate throughout Golden Canyon.- Chapter 7, Chapter 8 -


James Klein has been having problems since his return from Iraq, but Dr. Ruiz didn’t realize the extent of them. God is a bug and the sands blow in thick and hot.

Their lives.Golden Canyon’s abusive orderly gets his just desserts.- Chapter 15 -Dr. Sarah McManus discovers firsthand just how depraved the infectious madness at Golden Canyon can get. Tilly comes to Golden Canyon to meet the man who molested her as a child. Her therapy won’t be complete, she knows, until she writes one final letter from this place to Dollie.- Chapter 16 -A maddening secret behind Golden Canyon is revealed.- Chapter 17 -As the plague takes over the hospital, Skylar deals firsthand with the pandemonium now surrounding her.No one has ever believed Trisha. story:
The Story

Sinkhole: A Natural History of Suicide tells two stories: a personal story of the legacy of suicide in my family and a story of the boom-to-bust growth of an American mining town. I'm writing about my family's original home--Pittsburg, Kansas--and about its history as one of the largest coal mining regions in the country. I'm also writing about the life and death of my father and both my grandfathers--all of whom died by suicide. My maternal grandfather’s family (his father and four brothers) worked throughout their lives in the coal mines. My paternal grandfather served two terms in the U.S. House of Representatives and fought for worker's rights, including those of coal miners. This is an American story that is also emblematic of a piece of history.

The Impact

There are roughly 36,000 deaths by suicide in America every year. With roughly six people touched by each suicide, the number of survivors is considerable, and growing. Yet, why do we hear so little about suicide? In part, because it's a different kind of tragedy; murders make news, most suicides don't.
 
Suicide also carries a strong taboo, and most of us don't discuss it much. The stories that surround a suicide are often buried in silence, and the lives that end in suicide can become framed by this silence, leaving lasting effects of trauma on families--and on generations.
 
Sinkhole is my attempt to explore the impact of suicide on my family at a very personal level, exploring what it means to have a voice--as a writer, as a suicide survivor and as a mortal human being. In this work, I also explore how the destruction of the natural world serves as a metaphor for our own self-destruction.

The Need

Because of the emotional nature of the material and the research involved so far, this project represents the slowest and most careful writing I’ve ever undertaken. The work of this project, in particular, has required contemplative time that supports both the conception of the project and the drafting of new material. Likewise, to understand the history of Pittsburg and my father’s origins more fully, this project requires research and travel throughout Southeastern Kansas.

A portion of this manuscript was awarded the 2011 Arts & Letters Susan Atefat Prize in Non-Fiction; other recent awards include a 2012 Minnesota Emerging Writer's Grant, and a fellowship from the Minnesota State Arts Board. Funding from these sources has helped me to complete nearly all of my research and draft the first half of the book. This campaign is designed to build off this momentum of support and help me meet the goal of completing a full-length draft by Spring 2013. Now more than ever I’m realizing how much I need to focus on this project so it can be completed—and more importantly, shared. 

My overhead is low, but I still have expenses to meet. My target goal is $8,000, which will cover a portion of my basic expenses through April 2013. Like many artists, I string together a modest income through a variety of freelance jobs that allow me flexibility and time in the studio. Your contribution will help me keep my work load to a minimum over the next six months, so I can spend more time writing. 

By contributing to this campaign, you're also investing in the grassroots principle of crowdfunding, an idea vital to our future. In these difficult economic and political times, it seems important that we all come together to share resources, give to each other to support ideas we believe in and grow our collective power.

There are many ways for you to participate: as a fan, sponsor, devotee, patron, or angel and the perks, one of a kind.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're personally unable to contribute, please spread the word via e-mail, Facebook. Twitter, love letter, or postcard to others who might be interested or able to contribute. Please help me make the most of this opportunity. Thank you!

What People Are Saying

"Meditative and powerful; visceral and gentle; cerebral and from the heart. These words describe Juliet Patterson's writing. She's that rare breed of writer who can blend poetry with prose to create a piece of writing with substance and beauty. It's been a year since I read portions of Sinkhole: A Natural Hsitory of Suicide, and I can still feel the emotional impact of the images I read. They have stayed with me and become a part of my life, making me, I think, a more compassionate person in many ways. This, to me, is one of the main purposes of writing: to make us all more human. Juliet Patterson's work does exactly that."

story_txt:
The Story
Sinkhole: A Natural History of Suicide tells two stories: a personal story of the legacy of suicide in my family and a story of the boom-to-bust growth of an American mining town. I'm writing about my family's original home--Pittsburg, Kansas--and about its history as one of the largest coal mining regions in the country. I'm also writing about the life and death of my father and both my grandfathers--all of whom died by suicide. My maternal grandfather’s family (his father and four brothers) worked throughout their lives in the coal mines. My paternal grandfather served two terms in the U.S. House of Representatives and fought for worker's rights, including those of coal miners. This is an American story that is also emblematic of a piece of history.
The Impact
There are roughly 36,000 deaths by suicide in America every year. With roughly six people touched by each suicide, the number of survivors is considerable, and growing. Yet, why do we hear so little about suicide? In part, because it's a different kind of tragedy; murders make news, most suicides don't.
 
Suicide also carries a strong taboo, and most of us don't discuss it much. The stories that surround a suicide are often buried in silence, and the lives that end in suicide can become framed by this silence, leaving lasting effects of trauma on families--and on generations.
 

Sinkhole is my attempt to explore the impact of suicide on my family at a very personal level, exploring what it means to have a voice--as a writer, as a suicide survivor and as a mortal human being. In this work, I also explore how the destruction of the natural world serves as a metaphor for our own self-destruction.
The Need
Because of the emotional nature of the material and the research involved so far, this project represents the slowest and most careful writing I’ve ever undertaken. The work of this project, in particular, has required contemplative time that supports both the conception of the project and the drafting of new material. Likewise, to understand the history of Pittsburg and my father’s origins more fully, this project requires research and travel throughout Southeastern Kansas.
A portion of this manuscript was awarded the 2011 Arts & Letters Susan Atefat Prize in Non-Fiction; other recent awards include a 2012 Minnesota Emerging Writer's Grant, and a fellowship from the Minnesota State Arts Board. Funding from these sources has helped me to complete nearly all of my research and draft the first half of the book. This campaign is designed to build off this momentum of support and help me meet the goal of completing a full-length draft by Spring 2013. Now more than ever I’m realizing how much I need to focus on this project so it can be completed—and more importantly, shared. 
My overhead is low, but I still have expenses to meet. My target goal is $8,000, which will cover a portion of my basic expenses through April 2013. Like many artists, I string together a modest income through a variety of freelance jobs that allow me flexibility and time in the studio. Your contribution will help me keep my work load to a minimum over the next six months, so I can spend more time writing. 
By contributing to this campaign, you're also investing in the grassroots principle of crowdfunding, an idea vital to our future. In these difficult economic and political times, it seems important that we all come together to share resources, give to each other to support ideas we believe in and grow our collective power.
There are many ways for you to participate: as a fan, sponsor, devotee, patron, or angel and the perks, one of a kind.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you're personally unable to contribute, please spread the word via e-mail, Facebook. Twitter, love letter, or postcard to others who might be interested or able to contribute. Please help me make the most of this opportunity. Thank you!


What People Are Saying
"Meditative and powerful; visceral and gentle; cerebral and from the heart. These words describe Juliet Patterson's writing. She's that rare breed of writer who can blend poetry with prose to create a piece of writing with substance and beauty. It's been a year since I read portions of Sinkhole: A Natural Hsitory of Suicide, and I can still feel the emotional impact of the images I read. They have stayed with me and become a part of my life, making me, I think, a more compassionate person in many ways. This, to me, is one of the main purposes of writing: to make us all more human. story:
****$10,000 IN 8 DAYS! THANK YOU!****
See below for our new stretch goals!

 

NOTE REGARDING CLAIMING PERKS: TO CLAIM A PERK, PLEASE CLICK ON THE BUTTON NEAREST THE PERK YOU WOULD LIKE. CLICKING ON THE "BACK IT" BUTTON AT THE TOP MEANS YOU WISH TO MAKE A DONATION WITHOUT CLAIMING A PERK.  DO CONTACT US ASAP IF YOU THINK YOU MADE A MISTAKE!



We are Kyoto Journal.

For 30 years our all-volunteer team, based in Kyoto and around the world, have been crafting a magazine showcasing thought-provoking insights from Asia. We have won several independent press awards, including the Utne Reader and Pushcart Prizes, and also received recognition from the Japanese Ministry of Cultural Affairs.

 

We are dedicated to giving a platform to writers and new perspectives from all over the Asia region. But we also delight in coming back to our roots in the ancient capital of Japan; our beloved home, and a remarkable city we consider to be a kind of cultural crossroads.

Our Small Buildings of Kyoto book is dedicated to the quaint homes, businesses, workshops, as well as the occasional neighbourhood shrine and teahouse, that make up the lifeblood of the city. A far cry from the grand old temples they may be, but we believe the distinct personalities these buildings acquire and the insights they offer into the lives of ordinary citizens makes them invaluable cultural assets.

 

Support our book. Support independent publishing.

The Small Buildings of Kyoto project began in early 2016 when our founder John Einarsen began sharing pictures from his daily bicycle journeys through the city at the @kyotojournal instagram page. These images have proven to be so popular, and in response to demand we decided to compile them into a little book.

 

  

We would like to print 500 copies of Small Buildings of Kyoto. The book will be printed by a wonderful team in South Korea who have worked with us over the past 3 years, with a special limited edition hand-bound by a Kyoto craftswoman.

 

 

This is our third Indiegogo campaign -- both our previous crowdfunds exceeded their goals and you can be sure we will deliver. Any additional contributions beyond our funding goal will support Kyoto Journal in continuing its work as a fully independent publication.  To celebrate 30 years of publishing in 2017, we will be releasing a revamp of our print edition and holding a retrospective exhibition of photography from our issues -- in one of Kyoto's small buildings.

 

STRETCH GOALS

Perks

Backers who donate $25 or more will receive a copy of the Small Buildings of Kyoto. We have fantastic perks on offer to bring the spirit of Kyoto into your home, and for those of you lucky enough to be in Kyoto, tickets and coupons for unforgettable events and experiences.
 

The Book

Tada! Featuring  over 100 photographs, the book is all yours if you donate $25 or more. It is soft-cover, sized at 150x155mm and printed on 55% recycled matte paper in Korea.

The Limited Edition is available with bundles priced at $100 or more, and will be hand-bound in Kyoto with a printed cloth cover by Muramatsu Kana of Suzumeya. Those who donate $100 or more will have their name printed in the back of the Limited Edition as a token of our appreciation. Watch this page for updates!

Kyoto: The Forest Within the Gate (Second Edition)

 

 

Our last successfully crowdfunded book is a transcendent journey in photographs and writings to Japan’s ancient capital, with haiku by Edith Shiffert; photography by John Einarsen; calligraphy by Rona Conti and illuminating essays by Marc P. Keane, Diane Durston and Takeda Yoshifumi. We have reached our stretch goal of $15,000 to print a special second edition as a tribute to Edith, with an additional essay by Maggie Chula, Edith's student and former President at the Tanka Society of America.


 

Kampai Sake Box & Sake Today (See Saké Bundle)

If you're lucky enough to live in California and be aged 21 and over, you can get your hands on a Kampai Sake Box! We're also offering a 6-month (3-box) subscription.

Kampai's mission is to "bring the beauty of sake to everyone. By helping you fall in love with sake and by increasing its consumption outside of Japan, we hope to allow sake brewers to continue to preserve this centuries-old art form."

 

 

And what better way to complete your saké experience than with the latest issue of Sake Today magazine! The world's first regular publication to specialize in Japan's national drink, it covers all aspects of saké: from the history, the breweries (both in Japan and abroad) to food pairing suggestions and recipes; together with travel specials, as well as bars and restaurant guides.

Ceramic cups by Kazu Oba (See Studio Kotokoto Bundle)

We are offering four elegant cups by Japanese potter Kazu Oba, generously donated by our friends at Studio Kotokoto, the San Diego-based store showcasing beautiful and distinctive handmade objects from Japan and around the world.

 

About Kazu

Ceramicist Kazu Oba migrated to the States from Japan at the tender age of 17. Initially trained in sculpture and working as a chef on the side, his ever-growing appreciation of the vessels he was using to serve food eventually led him to pursue pottery. He trained under master Karatsu potter Nakazato Takashi before returning to the US to set up his own studio in Colorado. You can read more about Kazu here.

Walk Japan 2-day Kyoto Tour 

(See Walk Japan Bundle)

We have two discounted places on a Walk Japan 2-day group Kyoto Tour without accommodation. The voucher will be  valid for use on any scheduled group Kyoto tour in 2017 advertised on the Walk Japan website (see Tour Dates and select "Kyoto Tour" from the dropdown)

Walk Japan is the pioneer of off-the-beaten-track walking tours of Japan and its Kyoto Tour is an exploration of the ancient capital's hidden gems and must-see sites, including the opportunity to gain insights into the chado tea ceremony. The makes a great add-on to its Nakasendo Way and Basho tours. Check out the itinerary.

*Tours are subject to availability, and reservations need to be made at least 4 weeks in advance.

Butohkan Performance Tickets

(See Butohkan Bundle)

We are offering four tickets for two different performances at Kyoto's exciting new venue: Butohkan. Choose between Underworld Flower by Yurabe Masami (shows 6pm and 8pm second and fourth Tuesdays of the month), or Ima Tenko's Hisoku (6pm and 8pm most Thursdays). Reservation is required at least 7 days prior at info@butohkan.jp

We will also send you a copy of KJ 88, featuring a profile of Ima Tenko, one of the original members of the internationally acclaimed Byakkosha butoh troupe.

KJ Special Themed Issues: Kyoto Lives & Kyoto Speaks (See Kyoto Bundle & Kyoto Bundle Deluxe)

KJ 70: Kyoto Lives

To mark its 70th publication, Kyoto Journal took the opportunity to focus in on Kyoto and its ongoing changes in the early 21st century, interviewing forty-one Kyoto residents. Receive a copy as part of our Kyoto Bundle and Kyoto Bundle Deluxe.

KJ 16: Kyoto Speaks

This special issue of Kyoto Journal records the voices of some fifty Kyotoites, on topics spanning art, business, street life, politics or food, and the Kyoto they knew five, twenty or fifty years prior. Receive a copy together with KJ 70 as part of our Kyoto Bundle Deluxe.

Yunomi Tea

(See Yunomi Bundle
& Yunomi Bundle Deluxe )

 

Our friends at Yunomi.life have sourced the finest green tea from plantations in Uji, Kyoto Prefecture. We are offering our lovely backers:

A 100g bag of Aged First Flush Kyoto Farm Direct Green Tea as part of the Yunomi Bundle.

A 100g bag of 2016 First Flush Kyoto Farm Direct Kabusecha Green Tea AND 30g Uji Matcha Ceremonial Grade as part of the Yunomi Bundle Deluxe.

Codes for use on the yunomi.life will be sent out after the campaign end.

 

KYOTOGRAPHIE Passports (See KYOTOGRAPHIE Bundle)

A highlight of Kyoto's cultural calendar, the 5th edition of the KYOTOGRAPHIE International Photography Festival will be held from April 15th–May 14th 2017 on the theme of “LOVE.” We have 20 passports on offer, granting access to all 14 exhibitions, shown in iconic Kyoto venues with original scenography. Don't miss it!

 

KYOTOGRAPHIE Bundle backers will also receive a copy of our digital issue KJ 81, which features an interview with the founders of the festival, Lucille Reyboz and Yusuke Nakanishi.

Kyoto Journal will be holding an exhibition as part of KG+, the satellite event of KYOTOGRAPHIE, on April 15th - May 7th at Gallery 108 (free entry). Come and see us!

Small Buildings of Kyoto Prints (See Photographic Print Bundle)

Choose one of five of the most popular images in our Small Buildings of Kyoto series, matted and printed on Hahnemühle paper.

 

1. Jizo Shrine

 

2. Hio-an Tea House

 

3. Wood Carpenter

 

4. Potted Plants

 

5. Esperanto Hall

 

Watercolours by Ichsan Harja (See Watercolour Bundle

& Yasaka Shrine Watercolour )

 

Founded over 1,000 years ago, Yasaka Shrine is one of Kyoto's iconic landmarks. The lucky backer who claims this special original watercolour by Ichsan (sized 56X38cm) will also receive a limited edition copy of Small Buildings.

 

 

OR choose one of five gorgeous, original watercolours (sized 20X30cm), and also receive a limited edition copy of Small Buildings. THREE REMAINING!

 

 

1. Kitano Machiya (Available)

 

2. Vegetable Shop by Nishiki Market (Available)

 

3. Kikuya Furniture Shop

 

4. Café Bibliotec

 

5. Café Independants (Available)

 

About the Ichsan

Indonesian artist and KJ contributor Ichsan Harja came to Kyoto in 2010 on a Nippon Foundation grant to document the city's heritage through the medium of watercolour painting — an extension of a long-standing project in his home country, where he compiled an award-winning book to raise awareness of urban conservation in Bandung, West Java. He says: "Most of my works are about a certain quality of light: the harsh autumn light with ultramarine-hued shadows, or unusual marmalade sky caused by a rare combination of late noon sunlight, low-hanging clouds and thin snow...I tried to convey a notion of universal, timeless beauty. I want the viewer to enjoy my work as is, without any pretext nor context. This universal beauty, I believe, will enhance any historic and cultural meaning embodied by the original object."

You can find out more about Ichsan and his work at: http://watercolorichsan.com/

Private Night-Time Photography Tour with Stuart Gibson

Brush up your nighttime photography skills with long-time Kyoto resident Stuart Gibson. Beginning at sunset, Stuart will take you to see some of the city's hotspots in a different light – from a historic pagoda silhouetted against the sunset to the backstreets of Gion. If you are lucky, you may even encounter some of Kyoto's elusive Geisha. We are offering a private tour with Stuart for 2-3 people valid on Fridays and Saturdays through 2017. Please note this is still subject to Stuart's availability and you will need to reserve in advance. Start and end times also vary depending on the time of year. See the terms of booking a tour here.

 

About Stuart

Scotsman Stuart Gibson has devoted nearly every spare moment to photography since arriving in Kyoto 14 years ago. "If you are like me, you want more than just holiday snaps —you want images that really capture the essence of a time and place, and that's precisely what you'll have the chance to do on these tours. With the peace-of-mind of being with an experienced photographer who knows the area you are sure to get images to be proud of."

You can find Stuart's photography in our issues KJ 84 and 88.

KJ Print Issues (See Ultimate KJ Bundle)

Backers who give $500 will have a choice of 5 of KJ's printed back issues, plus our special first edition books Kyoto the Forest Within the Gate in hardcover and In a Rocket Made of Ice. Our shop can be found here.

Risks & Challenges

We are an all-volunteer team, and so while we try our best, sometimes we end up rushing to meet deadlines! With many varied perks and contributors involved, there is always the risk of some delay. The perks that are more time-sensitive will be prioritized accordingly. This is our third Indiegogo campaign, and our two previous crowdfunds exceeded their funding goals. You can rest assured your gifts will reach you!

Spread the word!

Remember to use the Indiegogo sharing tools when letting your friends know about our campaign!

If you are a retailer and interested in stocking Small Buildings, please send us a note at sales@kyotojournal.org

 

© Kyoto Journal 2017, all rights reserved.

FAQs

How do I claim a perk?

Hover your cursor over the different perks on the right hand side of the page to reveal the purchase button.

Clicking "back it" at the top of the page will allow you to donate to the campaign without claiming a perk.

story:
Thank you for taking the time to come and look at my campaign for funding. The money being raised will go towards the publication of my children's picture book "Who We Are". The story raises awareness of our connectivity to other beings and the beauty that lives within us all. 


I have always loved writing and found it easier to express  myself  through  my fingers  rather than verbally.  Over the last few years I have been on a journey that has led me to find myself, my true self, something that most of us lose  whilst trying to fit in society. I hope this book is a stepping stone, a little reminder for younger generations so they never forget who they are.  With so much emphasis on building exteriors our children and ourselves begin to neglect what's within us.  "Who We Are"  is my first project in working towards making changes to how children view themselves.

The story raises awareness of our connectivity to other beings and the beauty that lives within us all. I have always loved writing and found it easier to express  myself  through  my fingers  rather than verbally.  Over the last few years I have been on a journey that has led me to find myself, my true self, something that most of us lose  whilst trying to fit in society. I hope this book is a stepping stone, a little reminder for younger generations so they never forget who they are.  With so much emphasis on building exteriors our children and ourselves begin to neglect what's within us.  "Who We Are"  is my first project in working towards making changes to how children view themselves.

story:
Short Summary

Flower Crown Magazine is a new digital magazine for young intersectional feminists! We are about having fun but not at the expense of the marginalized. We believe in the power of choice but we believe in examining those choices as well. We believe in body positivity! We believe in sex positivity that doesn't exclude asexuals. We believe in fighting for our sisters not just our cisters. And we resent and call out the silencing and erasure of women of color. We believe in self love. We are a lifestyle magazine with a socially conscious lean.

Thank you for viewing our Indiegogo campaign! 

Here are the first two issues

Flower Crown Mag: Issue 1

Flower Crown Mag: Issue 2

What We Need & What You Get

  • We will be using the money you donate to pay the cost of publication, keep the magazine free, pay for our Wordpress this year and to help get our writers and photographers to assignments around New York City. 
  • To thank you for your help, we will save ad space for donors and shout out your blog on the site. Please keep in mind that we are a social justice oriented magazine so we reserve the right to not promote blogs and bloggers that are harmful to any groups of people.
  • If we do not reach our goal the money we receive will go towards helping us pay the publication costs.

The Impact

Young women, especially marginalized young women, are searching all over to see themselves and the things that concern them represented. Young women are much smarter than most magazines give them credit for. They care about the world around them, they see the issues and want something done about them, and they recognize that there is a huge flaw in the portrayal and treatment of women the world over. We want to give them a place where they can the real world and how they fit in it. We want to start a community of young women who care about intersectionality and to create space for their dialogue.

    Risks & Challenges

    Our risks in creating this magazine is funding ourselves in the future. We plan to open a store for the magazine, seek advertisement from brands/shops who uphold our beliefs, and to use the funds from that to keep the magazine free.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    • Please spread the word about our magazine and about this Indiegogo campaign. We'd be eternally grateful.

story:
Since age eleven, I've dreamed of traveling to the United Kingdom to study creative writing at a British university. It is the birth place of the English language and would be the perfect destination to exercise my independence before attending college. Let's be honest, studying in England is quite the dream for a sixteen year old without a job, but even though I'm short on funds, I'm not short on determination. I started this fund in hopes of raising enough money for the airfare and application fees for this program and also for help in promoting literacy to other children around the world.

I not only want to hone my writing skills; I want to use my passion for words to help make a difference in the world. Two years ago, I started a program called "Words on Wings," to help promote literacy to children in need around the world. So far, my program has taken flight to orphanages and poverty stricken areas in Peru, Mexico and Jamaica. This year, I plan to bring my program home to help children in need in my own community. I'm also using my words and voice to help protect and improve the lives of children by serving on the Mayors Young Leaders Advisory Council and our cities Youth Council. Please help me fulfill my goal to further my education, and to help promote literacy to children around the world.

Even the smallest donation can help make a big difference in my life and in the lives of the many children I reach through “Words on Wings.” Thank you for your support-it makes a world of difference

story:
Hello, welcome to the indiegogo page to get Casey Rocheteau to her new home in Detroit. Casey was granted the inaugural Write A House residency in Detroit, but needs help with moving expenses. For every dollar donated, Write a House will match donations up to $1000. Please consider donating to this campaign, for the perks, the glory, and bragging rights!

What We Need

Uhaul rental, gas money, and funds to break a rental lease in Brooklyn, totaling over $2300

What You Get

Check out the list of perks to your right. You  can get a signed copy  of Casey's work Knocked Up  On Yes, one of her two albums on the Whitehaus Family Record, and a print of a tarot card  designed by Casey  for a  forthcoming  project.  Check out the examples here to get  an idea.

    The Impact

    Write A House and Detroit Young Builders have done so much to get this initial Write A House up and running, and your donation supports a writer in need as well as building a strong literary community in Detroit.

    Write A House's mission:

    Write-A-House (WAH) is a Detroit based organization that seeks to teach and support trade crafts and literary creativity. Our key tactic involves leveraging the easy availability of distressed housing in order to promote vocational education, home ownership, neighborhood stabilization, and creative arts. In short, WAH will work to support a more vibrant literary arts community that lives at a grassroots level and helps Detroit’s neighborhoods.

    for more, visit: http://writeahouse.com/

      Other Ways You Can Help

      spread this campaign online!

      Pre-order Casey's book Knocked Up on Yes: http://caseyrocheteau.org/wares/

      And finally, as a new homeowner, Casey needs to furbish her home. While she, family and friends have covered most of the basics the following is a short list of items that would also be very useful:

      cookware (pots, pans, baking sheets, etc), gas cards, shelves, house paint/tarps/painting supplies, pull out couch, coffee table, books on Detroit, poetry books, artwork, coffee maker.

story:
La Novela

El exdetective de policía John Hart no pudo salvarlos y murieron por culpa de su miedo a las alturas. Ahora vive alcoholizado, apartados de todos. Un día se despierta en lo alto de un trampolín en medio de una antigua prisión. Desde allí escucha los gritos de sus seres queridos: el amor de su vida, un niño al que juró proteger y su segunda madre, atrapados en trampas que explotan sus propios miedos.
          Incapaz de moverse, tendrá que ser capaz de vencer su fobia para salvarlos, pero el psicópata que ha organizado todo tiene preparadas más sorpresas: un asesino de policías al que John encerró, un violador, un pirómano y un maestro de la tortura intentarán darle caza por separado. Los protagonistas deberán superar sus terrores más profundos y enfrentarse a estos monstruos creados por la sociedad para poder escapar de la prisión. No todos lo conseguirán… Quizás ninguno lo haga…

El Autor

Fernando C. de la Haza nació en Sevilla en 1980. Es Licenciado en Económicas por la Universidad de Sevilla y diplomado en Gestión y Comercio Internacional en Montpellier (Francia). Ha trabajado durante más de seis años en distintos proyectos internacionales, en países como Libia, Camerún, Túnez y Ecuador, alternándolos con algunos trabajos en su ciudad natal o viajes a través de Europa, Asia y América.

Gran apasionado de la lectura, con su primera novela El juego de Jack Crowe, consiguió cumplir su sueño de entrar a formar parte del mundo literario. Ahora, con su nueva obra, Las trampas del miedo, se adentra en el thriller psicológico, logrando captar la atención del lector desde el inicio al sumergirlo en un mundo de fobias y oscuros deseos.

Una Muestra

«—¡Socorroo! ¡Qué alguien me ayude!
          El pequeño Bobby gritó una vez más con todas sus fuerzas. Ya no le quedaban lágrimas suficientes para seguir llorando. Le costaba respirar y los temblores se habían vuelto más fuertes. No podía separar las manos de los ojos. No quería verla. Le daba miedo. Le perseguía en sus sueños…
          El agua.
          Allí vivían los monstruos…
          —¡Otra vez no, por favor!, ¡Otra vez no! —repetía a cada momento intentando encontrar la manera de calmarse. No podía sufrir un ataque. No sin su madre al lado.
          No debía pensar en ella, pero era incapaz de evitarlo. No podía mirarla. El agua maldita. Le daba miedo y lo paralizaba. No podía moverse ni salir corriendo porque le rodeaba. Los hombres malvados la habían puesto ahí. También le daban miedo, sobre todo el encapuchado de ojos azules. No le gustaba esa mirada, aunque nunca, nunca sería peor que el agua…
          —¡Mamáaa! ¿¿Dónde estás??
          Llevaba casi dos horas de pie en una pequeña columna situada en el centro de una gran piscina. Tenía hambre y sueño. Desde el día anterior no había dormido prácticamente nada. Había sido un día estupendo hasta que los hombres malos le cogieron. No solo estupendo, estaba siendo uno de los mejores de su vida. Por primera vez, una chica le había dado un beso. En la mejilla buena, claro. La otra estaba quemada de cuando su papá le había castigado por romper, sin querer, una botella de ron.
         Wendy se le había acercado y le había dicho:
         —Hola Bobby, me gustas. Eres muy divertido. —Se puso de puntillas, le dio un beso e inmediatamente se dio la vuelta y corrió sin mirar atrás. Todo había durado menos de cinco segundos, pero habían sido los cinco segundos más maravillosos de su vida».

El Objetivo

En esta campaña preventa nos hemos propuesto alcanzar el equivalente a 55 reservas, es decir, 980€, recibiendo quienes participen el libro en su casa sin gastos de envío (en España) antes de que entre en circulación... existiendo incluso la opción de reservar el libro con tu nombre en los agradecimientos por un poco más del precio de venta, como detalle exclusivo.

También, usando la opción BACK IT, podéis realizar donaciones a la edición; opción a través de la cual no se os pedirá dirección de envío porque no conlleva contraprestación de ningún tipo.

Media

Por otro lado, independientemente de que colaboréis realizando vuestra reserva o no, en ocasiones no se puede, sería una inestimable ayuda que os hicieseis eco de esta campaña a través del boca-oreja o por redes sociales... la Cultura, Distrito 93 y Fernando C. de la Haza os lo agradeceremos.

story:
Story of My Book

Who’s Doing It? is a book about humility. It’s a book about failure. It’s a book about successful young entrepreneurs that have refused to wait until they were ready to follow their dreams and took it upon themselves to make their mark.

My name is Johnny Bui and I am the author of Who’s Doing It? I wrote this book because I felt a greater calling to hold myself and my peers responsible for committing to where we want to be in our lives. We owe it to ourselves to do so. The opportunity to write a book serendipitously came along just as when I was completing my college transfer application to attend Babson College. I was at a point in my life where I gave what I was for who I could be. I saw Babson College as this place of entrepreneurship, huge innovation and achievement by the student body; a place of opportunity and competition that I would thrive in. So I spent the next 6 months putting my head down and working for this one opportunity to switch schools. So here I am, writing this from San Francisco at a Babson study away program — my point is, once we expose ourselves to something greater, we can’t ever settle for less. So if this is what our peers can do — what is the extent to what we can achieve? Why don’t we take that risk? These young entrepreneurs that I am proud to call my peers are doing it. And while I could have written about any young entrepreneur, I selected these particular entrepreneurs because of their locality; these are the entrepreneurs that you may not have heard about in mainstream media and that’s what makes them special. They are not famous in the traditional sense, which makes them relatable to you and I. However, fame is relative. These young entrepreneurs are the talk of their town, they have each individually started something that have in one way or another affected the lives of those around them as well as themselves.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover that as a young entrepreneur, creative, and/or individual, we are capable of more. In this book, I hope to instill the same type of passion and excitement that I have for youth empowerment in you. Coming from the perspective of a first generation background, it’s important to be exposed to and understand what is possible to achieve as a youth. It’s so easy to get stuck thinking that the world is small because of your daily routine but if you can see what other people (not that different from you) can do - maybe that will get you thinking. And that’s exactly what I want you to do. Then ultimately I want you to see this book as a tool to help you realign your goals into a reality - that because some can achieve great success, it is proof that others can at well. It is the biggest obligation that we have to ourselves, to try.

In this book, you'll learn about staying on your own unique path and coping with failure/setbacks from stories like the following:

  • Ariana Feygin - How she failed twice before earning her chance to compete on MasterChef Junior
  • David Zamarin - How he began his entrepreneurial journey selling G-Shocks and Beats before starting his Shark Tank winning company DetraPel
  • Brennan Stark - How he began building sustainable homes for his community without any construction experience

You will love this book if you love seeing young people do big things and enjoy reading a hero/heroine’s journey.

Who’s Doing It? is a non-fiction book that speaks to rising college students and ambitious high school students who are looking at what their role is in the world and how they hope to play a part for the first time.

 

The Book - Who’s Doing It?


The book is written in 3 Parts.

Part 1 contains the introduction + prologue. Here, I share my personal story about how I’ve applied the message of this book to my own life and the ‘it’ mindset that will be discussed throughout the book. Additionally, from this section of the book, the reader will get a greater scope of what to expect for the rest of the book followed by Ariana Feygin, Season 6 contestant of MasterChef Junior, and the story of how she rose from Excelsior, Minnesota to competing with other young chefs on the grandest stage of them all. Indicative of the stories to come, Ariana’s story is all about taking 1 step forward and 3 steps back on the way to conquering her goals.

Part 2 contains Chapters 1-2. This part focuses on recognizing one’s curiosity and taking small steps to draw that curiosity out through action. The chapter follows the stories of several young entrepreneurs who saw things a little differently and decided to push back on conventional norms. These chapters include stories of the power of saying ‘yes’ to opportunity and showing that youth and inexperience are not always weaknesses.

Part 3 contains Chapters 3-5. This part discusses the the other side of entrepreneurship that is not often talked about. It dives into the battle with inexperience, fear, hesitation, and ultimately when your world crumbs down when things don’t work out the way you want it to. Why? Because it’s important to know that an entrepreneur’s journey is one with many challenges along the way and these young entrepreneurs are no exception. It was important for me to share their difficulties and setbacks with the reader because it would help shed the persona that entrepreneurship is ‘easy’ and that its the fast track to getting rich. In these chapters, readers will discover the stumbling blocks that these young entrepreneurs faced while growing their business/putting their business together and the wisdom to conquer them.
 

What I Need & What You'll Get


This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:
 
  • The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in February, 2020.
  • The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!
  • The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)
  • The Copyediting for My Book - to make help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication
  • The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this Spring of 2020

When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.


I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:

  • You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish
  • A Personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book
  • Your Name will appear in a Special, Acknowledgements Section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)
  • Early access to the Introduction of my Book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
  • The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
  • I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share experience the experiences of writing my book
  • And more...

About the Author


Johnny Bui is a first semester senior at Babson College, concentrating in Strategic Management and Entrepreneurship. He is proactive, deep thinking, and is relentlessly passionate about pursuing a life of zero complacency. He enjoys practicing self-improvement, minimalism, and travel. He is interested in strategy, technology, and consulting.

Johnny wrote this book because the opportunity to do so arose at a point in his life where he realized that we as individuals are capable of achieving more - given our own permission. He was at a crossroads in his life of being content with what he had, or taking a chance at changing his world. In that latter decision, he became influence by what other young colleagues were doing - how they had become so accomplished at a young age and how there seemed to be no limit to what they can achieve. The spark of inspiration is what drove him to go all in on his transfer application and share the stories of the entrepreneurs that motivate him. He believes that the mindset of wanting to be better than oneself is the central element to ascend from one’s certain circumstance.

Johnny Bui

Story of My Book
Who’s Doing It? is a book about humility. It’s a book about failure. It’s a book about successful young entrepreneurs that have refused to wait until they were ready to follow their dreams and took it upon themselves to make their mark.My name is Johnny Bui and I am the author of Who’s Doing It? I wrote this book because I felt a greater calling to hold myself and my peers responsible for committing to where we want to be in our lives. We owe it to ourselves to do so. The opportunity to write a book serendipitously came along just as when I was completing my college transfer application to attend Babson College. I was at a point in my life where I gave what I was for who I could be. I saw Babson College as this place of entrepreneurship, huge innovation and achievement by the student body; a place of opportunity and competition that I would thrive in. So I spent the next 6 months putting my head down and working for this one opportunity to switch schools. So here I am, writing this from San Francisco at a Babson study away program — my point is, once we expose ourselves to something greater, we can’t ever settle for less. So if this is what our peers can do — what is the extent to what we can achieve? Why don’t we take that risk? These young entrepreneurs that I am proud to call my peers are doing it. And while I could have written about any young entrepreneur, I selected these particular entrepreneurs because of their locality; these are the entrepreneurs that you may not have heard about in mainstream media and that’s what makes them special. They are not famous in the traditional sense, which makes them relatable to you and I. However, fame is relative. These young entrepreneurs are the talk of their town, they have each individually started something that have in one way or another affected the lives of those around them as well as themselves.My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover that as a young entrepreneur, creative, and/or individual, we are capable of more. In this book, I hope to instill the same type of passion and excitement that I have for youth empowerment in you. Coming from the perspective of a first generation background, it’s important to be exposed to and understand what is possible to achieve as a youth. It’s so easy to get stuck thinking that the world is small because of your daily routine but if you can see what other people (not that different from you) can do - maybe that will get you thinking. And that’s exactly what I want you to do. Then ultimately I want you to see this book as a tool to help you realign your goals into a reality - that because some can achieve great success, it is proof that others can at well. It is the biggest obligation that we have to ourselves, to try.In this book, you'll learn about staying on your own unique path and coping with failure/setbacks from stories like the following:

Ariana Feygin - How she failed twice before earning her chance to compete on MasterChef Junior
David Zamarin - How he began his entrepreneurial journey selling G-Shocks and Beats before starting his Shark Tank winning company DetraPel
Brennan Stark - How he began building sustainable homes for his community without any construction experience

You will love this book if you love seeing young people do big things and enjoy reading a hero/heroine’s journey.
Who’s Doing It? is a non-fiction book that speaks to rising college students and ambitious high school students who are looking at what their role is in the world and how they hope to play a part for the first time.

The book is written in 3 Parts.Part 1 contains the introduction + prologue. Here, I share my personal story about how I’ve applied the message of this book to my own life and the ‘it’ mindset that will be discussed throughout the book. Additionally, from this section of the book, the reader will get a greater scope of what to expect for the rest of the book followed by Ariana Feygin, Season 6 contestant of MasterChef Junior, and the story of how she rose from Excelsior, Minnesota to competing with other young chefs on the grandest stage of them all. Indicative of the stories to come, Ariana’s story is all about taking 1 step forward and 3 steps back on the way to conquering her goals.Part 2 contains Chapters 1-2. This part focuses on recognizing one’s curiosity and taking small steps to draw that curiosity out through action. The chapter follows the stories of several young entrepreneurs who saw things a little differently and decided to push back on conventional norms. These chapters include stories of the power of saying ‘yes’ to opportunity and showing that youth and inexperience are not always weaknesses.Part 3 contains Chapters 3-5. This part discusses the the other side of entrepreneurship that is not often talked about. It dives into the battle with inexperience, fear, hesitation, and ultimately when your world crumbs down when things don’t work out the way you want it to. Why?
